This case is to be tried to a jury, pending Plaintiffs anticipated motion to extend the time to file a jury demand. No additional parties may be joined after April 19, 2014 without leave of court. No additional causes of action or defenses may be asserted after April 19, 2014 without leave of court. All fact discovery is to be completed no later than October 17, 2014. Depositions shall be completed by August 18, 2014. All expert discovery, including disclosures, reports, production of underlying documents, and depositions shall be completed by October 17, 2014. All discovery shall be completed no later than October 17, 2014. The Court will conduct a post-discovery conference on July 2, 2014 at 11:00 a.m. The parties have conferred and their present best estimate of the length of trial is three to four days. The parties are directed to submit a status letter to the Court by May 30, 2014 and indicate whether a referral to Magistrate Judge or Mediator would be productive at that time. ( Amended Pleadings due by 4/19/2014. Joinder of Parties due by 4/19/2014. Deposition due by 10/17/2014. Fact Discovery due by 10/17/2014. Expert Discovery due by 10/17/2014. Original Docket Text: MEMO ENDORSEMENT on re: 56 Letter filed by Beautyko, LLC. ENDORSEMENT: All discovery shall be stayed as to NoMoreRack.com, Inc. pending resolution of Defendant's motion to compel arbitration. Plaintiff's counsel is directed to advise his client that the Court may award NoMoreRack.com, Inc. reasonable attorneys' fees and costs if it finds that Plaintiff has acted in bad faith in opposing NoMoreRack.com's motion to compel arbitration. See Amaprop Ltd. v. Indiabulls Fin. Servs. Ltd., 10 Civ. 1853 PGG, 2011 WL 1002439, at *3(S.D.N.Y. Mar. 16, 2011 ) ("In cases involving unfounded opposition to petitions to compel arbitration, courts have awarded attorneys' fees where the party refusing arbitration acted without justification or did not have a reasonable chance to prevail." Original Docket Text: ORDER denying 57 Letter Motion for Adjournment of Settlement Conference. The request to cancel the settlement conference scheduled for October 9 is respectfully denied. The Court believes that the parties should make their best efforts to settle this case at this juncture, before deposition discovery proceeds. The Court is mindful of plaintiff's concern that Ms. Kuczkir's participation from South Carolina may make things more difficult, and, to that end, the Court is working with her counsel to see if it is feasible for Ms. Kuczkir to participate via a video teleconference. In any event, the parties and their counsel are reminded of two important principles in anticipation of the settlement conference. First, as noted in my Standing Order for Settlement, "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view - until you climb into his skin and walk around in it." (from Harper Lee's "To Kill A Mockingbird") The parties and their counsel should make all efforts to see the case through the other side's eyes as they prepare for the conference. Second, as President Lincoln once exhorted: "Discourage litigation. Persuade your neighbors to compromise whenever you can. Point out to them how the nominal winner is often a real loser - in fees, expenses, and waste of time. As a peacemaker, the lawyer has a superior opportunity of being a good man. There will be business enough." Counsel are directed to share this order, and the quotes cited herein, with their clients in advance of the conference and further directed to come to the conference with an open mind. (HEREBY ORDERED by Magistrate Judge James L. Cott)(Text Only Order) (Cott, James) (Entered: 09/30/2014)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION AND ORDER FOR CONSOLIDATION. IT XS HEREBY STIPULATED AND AGREED, by and between the undersigned counsel for all parties, that: 1. The following actions are related actions: a. Martin Friedman v. Mary Kuczkir a/k/a Fern Michaels, Pak6 Inc., and KAP5, Inc., Case No. 14-cv-130; and b. Mary Kuczkir a/k/a Fern Michaels, Pak6, Inc., First Draft, Inc. and MRK Productions, Inc. v. McLaughlin & Stern, LLP and Martin Friedman, Case No. 14-cv-9060. 2. Pursuant to Federal Rules of Civil Procedure Rule 42, the above-captioned actions are hereby consolidated. 3. These actions shall be referred to herein as the "Consolidated Actions." 4. Every pleading in this Consolidated Action shall bear the caption written above. 5. The Parties agree that discovery in either case, whether conducted prior to or after the date of this Stipulation, will also be part of and applicable to the Consolidated Actions for all purposes. 6. Pursuant to this consolidation, defendants in the First Action will withdraw and dismiss the First Counterclaim asserted in their Answer in the First Action, which sounds in legal malpractice, because that cause of action is duplicative of causes of action assel1ed in the Second Action. 7. McLaughlin & Stern and Friedman will file their Answer to the First Amended Complaint filed in the Second Action on or before 30 days from the date hereof, and may also serve their written discovery demands at that time. 8. The parties agree to vacate the current Discovery Scheduling Order in the First Action, and agree that they will submit a new joint Discovery Plan for the Consolidated Actions within thirty (30) days of when this stipulation is so-ordered. 9. This Stipulation is without prejudice to any other rights that any party may have. 10. This Stipulation may be executed in counterparts and electronic or facsimile signatures shall be treated as originals. This Stipulation may, when fully executed, be filed via ECF by any of the parties. (Signed by Judge John G. Koeltl on 1/28/2015) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:14-cv-00130-JGK, 1:14-cv-09060-JGK. Original Docket Text: ORDER: By order dated August 3, 2015 (Dkt. No. 108), Judge Koeltl has referred these related cases to me for general pre-trial supervision. The parties have presented three letter-motions to the Court (Dkt. Nos. 97, 100, and 102) and the Court will accordingly hold a conference on August 13, 2015 at 2:30 p.m. to address the issues raised by the parties in their respective correspondence. The conference will take place in courtroom 21-D at 500 Pearl Street, New York, New York. In advance of the conference, the Court directs counsel to further meet and confer to review the various issues raised in the correspondence to the Court in an effort to see whether some or all of the issues may be resolved or at least narrowed without judicial involvement. The parties should report to the Court, by letter, no later than August 12, 2015 which issues, if any, they have been able to resolve. The Court expects civility and professionalism in all interactions that counsel have with each other during the meet-and-confer as well as in any court proceedings. Status Conference set for 8/13/2015 at 02:30 PM before Magistrate Judge James L. Cott. (Signed by Magistrate Judge James L. Cott on 8/5/2015) (kgo) (Entered: 08/05/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: The Court held a conference on August 13, 2015 to address multiple outstanding discovery disputes set forth in two letter motions to the Court. (Dkt. Nos. 97, 100). The parties are directed to the transcript for the Court's rulings on the issues presented in these motions. Also at this conference, the Court addressed Kuczkir's motion seeking leave to move for summary judgment. (Dkt. No. 102). Counsel for Kuczkir will file a letter with the Court by August 27, 2015 advising whether they plan to file such a motion before the close of discovery in November. If Kuczkir does move for summary judgment, she must do so by September 14, 2015. Friedman and McLaughlin & Stem will then have until October 16, 2015 to file their opposition papers and Kuczkir will have until October 30, 2015 to reply. If Kuczkir does not move for summary judgment at this time, she may do so after the close of discovery (as may Friedman and McLaughlin & Stem). The Clerk of Court is directed to close docket entries 97, 100, and 102 in 14-CV-130 and docket entries 39 and 42 in 14-CV-9060. Motions due by 9/14/2015. Responses due by 10/16/2015 Replies due by 10/30/2015. (Signed by Magistrate Judge James L. Cott on 8/14/2015) (kgo) (Entered: 08/14/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER granting 129 Letter Motion for Discovery; granting 129 Letter Motion for Local Rule 37.2 Conference; granting 129 Letter Motion for Extension of Time to File Response/Reply ; denying 133 Letter Motion to Compel. The parties are directed to the transcript for the Court's rulings on these issues. However, for clarity's sake, the Court will summarize a number of those rulings herein. The Kuczkir parties are directed to provide to the Friedman parties forthwith the consultant agreement they have with Michael Bernstein. Lastly, the Friedman parties are permitted to reopen Bernstein's deposition for the limited scope discussed during the conference for a maximum of two hours. The Kuczkir parties are further directed to produce any outstanding discovery from Ms. Kuczkir by October 2 at 5:00 p.m. This directive includes, but is not limited to, retrieving any responsive deleted emails from Ms. Kuczkir's AOL account. The Court denies the Kuczkir parties' renewed request to obtain Mr. Friedman's tax returns. The Court denies the Kuczkir parties' application to disqualify Ms. Sash and Mr. Somoza. Finally, the Court extends the Friedman parties' time to file their opposition to the summary judgment motion to November 16 and the Kuczkir parties will have until December 7 to file any reply papers. The Clerk of Court is directed to close docket entries 128, 129, and 133 in 14-CV-130 and docket entries 67, 68 and 72 in 14-CV-9060. (As further set forth in this Order.) ( Responses due by 11/16/2015, Replies due by 12/7/2015.) (Signed by Magistrate Judge James L. Cott on 9/29/2015) (kgo) (Entered: 09/29/2015)

Original Docket Text: OPINION AND ORDER. The foregoing constitutes the Courts Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law. The Court has considered all of the arguments of the parties. To the extent not specifically addressed above, any remaining arguments are either moot or without merit. For the reasons explained above, Friedman is entitled to judgment on Counts One and Two in Action One for breach of contract and is entitled to judgment in the amount of the sum of all monies being held in escrow pending the outcome of this litigation, with 9% interest as calculated pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R.  5001. The remainder of the claims in Action One are dismissed as moot. The only remaining counterclaim in Action One is dismissed with prejudice. All of the Kuczkir Parties claims in Action Two are dismissed with prejudice. Friedman shall submit a proposed judgment within five days of the date of this opinion. The remaining parties may submit a counter judgment two days thereafter. Friedman may submit any responses two days after the counter judgments are submitted. The Clerk is directed to close all pending motions. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge John G. Koeltl on 8/9/17) (yv) (Entered: 08/09/2017)

Original Docket Text: OPINION of USCA as to 27 Corrected Notice of Appeal filed by Benihana of Tokyo, LLC USCA Case Number 14-0841. Defendantappellant Benihana of Tokyo, LLC appeals from a February 26, 2014 order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Paul A. Engelmayer, J.) granting the application of plaintiffappellee Benihana, Inc. for a preliminary injunction in aid of arbitration of a dispute arising under the parties license agreement. The district court enjoined Benihana of Tokyo from: (1) selling unauthorized food items at the restaurant it operates pursuant to the license agreement; (2) using certain trademarks in connection with the restaurant in a manner not approved by the license agreement; and (3) arguing to the arbitral panel, if it rules that Benihana of Tokyo breached the license agreement, that Benihana of Tokyo should be given additional time to cure any defaults. We conclude that the district court was within its discretion in granting the first and second components of the injunction. However, the district court erred in restricting the arguments Benihana of Tokyo may make to the arbitral panel. Catherine O'Hagan Wolfe, Clerk USCA for the Second Circuit. Certified: 04/28/2015. (nd) (Entered: 04/28/2015)

Original Docket Text: MANDATE of USCA (Certified Copy) as to 27 Corrected Notice of Appeal filed by Benihana of Tokyo, LLC. USCA Case Number 14-0841. The appeal in the above captioned case from an order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York was argued on the district court's record and the parties' briefs. Upon consideration thereof, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED, ADJUDGED and DECREED that the order of the district court is AFFIRMED insofar as it enjoins the Appellant, pending resolution of the arbitration, from selling hamburgers or other unauthorized menu items or engaging in unapproved advertising at its Hawaii location. The order is REVERSED insofar as it enjoins the Appellant from arguing to the arbitrators for an extended cure period. Catherine O'Hagan Wolfe, Clerk USCA for the Second Circuit. Issued As Mandate: 05/19/2015. (nd) (Entered: 05/19/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER denying without prejudice 49 Letter Motion for Leave to File Document. Benihana Inc.'s ("BI") request to file a supplemental affidavit in further support of its pending motion for an order of civil contempt against Benihana of Tokyo ("BOT") is denied. The Court's denial of Bi's request is expressly not for the reasons stated in BOT's opposition, Dkt. 50. Rather, the Court intends to resolve the pending, fully briefed motion based on the existing record, rather than complicating and delaying resolution of that matter by effectively expanding the record. This ruling is without prejudice to Bi's right to pursue appropriate relief for the new violations it alleges. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge Paul A. Engelmayer on 4/6/2016) (kl) (Entered: 04/06/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER denying 33 Motion for Sanctions. For that reason, BI's motion for sanctions for violations of the Preliminary Injunction is denied. Because the Court denies that motion, the Court denies BI's request for attorneys' fees incurred in litigating this motion as well. At the same time, the Court denies BOT's request for attorneys' fees in defending against BI's motion. That is because BI's bid for coercive sanctions, although resolved at a time when such sanctions were no longer viable, had a colorable, if not a compelling, basis at the time it was made. Notwithstanding its denial of BI's motion for sanctions for violations of the Preliminary Injunction as moot, the Court observes the following. In pertinent respects, the substance of the Preliminary Injunction has been recapitulated in the Permanent Injunction in 15 Civ. 7428 that took effect today when the Court adopted the arbitral panel's Award. And the parties have each recognized the Court's authority to enforce the Permanent Injunction, including by, if necessary, imposing coercive sanctions. See BI Supp. Br. 3-5; BOT Supp. Br. 2-7. The Court is hopeful that the parties will use this moment as a pivot, and attempt in good faith to repair their working relationship and amicably resolve the issues that have divided them. The disputes between BI and BOT have consumed far too much money, time, ink, and acrimony. Pending any renegotiation, however, the License Agreement governs the parties' relationship as it relates to the Benihana restaurant in Honolulu. In the event of a future motion to enforce the Court's Permanent Injunction-including based on BOT's use of advertisements, publicity, and signs that have not been approved by BI in accordance with Article 5.2 of the agreement-the Court's intention would be to resolve any such dispute with firmness and dispatch. Lest the point be unclear: The Court expects each party to punctiliously abide by the provisions of the agreement incorporated in the Permanent Injunction. The Clerk of Court is directed to close the motion pending at docket number 33 and to close this case. (As further set forth in this Order) (Signed by Judge Paul A. Engelmayer on 7/15/2016) (kl) (Entered: 07/15/2016)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: The Court is in receipt of Defense Attorney Martin Shell's request to be relieved as counsel dated April 10, 2017. (ECF No. 29.) He alleges he has been unable to communicate with his client. Corporations cannot appear pro se and must be represented by an attorney. See, e.g., Rowland v. Cal. Mens Colony, Unit II Men's Advisory Council, 506 U.S. 194, 201-02 (1993). Defendant has 60 days from the date of this Order to obtain a new attorney. Defendant is hereby put on notice that its failure to obtain new counsel will not be a defense against entry of default judgment against it. See, e.g., Premier Fla. Auto Sales & Leasing v. Mercedes-Benz of Massapequa, LLP, No. CV 10-4428 DRH WDW, 2012 WL 7149418, at *2 (E.D.N.Y. Nov. 5, 2012), report and recommendation adopted sub nom. Premier Fla. Auto Sales & Leasing, LLC v. Mercedes-Benz of Massapequa, LLC, No. 10 CV 4428 DRH WDW, 2013 WL 593506 (E.D.N.Y. Feb. 14, 2013) (entering default against an unrepresented corporate defendant and noting "[a] failure by a corporate defendant to obtain counsel constitutes a failure to defend because a corporation cannot proceed pro se."). Mr. Shell is directed to forward a copy of this Order to Defendant and to furnish the Court with all contact information for Defendant. (Signed by Judge Deborah A. Batts on 4/19/2017) (ap) (Entered: 04/19/2017)

Original Docket Text: JOINT STIPULATION TO VACATE BRIEFING OF DEFENDANTS' MOTION TO DISMISS PENDING RESOLUTION OF PLAINTIFFS' MOTION TO AMEND: NOW THEREFORE, the Parties, through their undersigned counsel, stipulate to and hereby request that the Court: (1) Vacate Plaintiffs' December 12, 2014 deadline to oppose the MTD and Defendants' December 19, 2014 deadline to reply until the Court decides the MTA; (2) Set the briefing schedule of the MTA to accommodate the upcoming holidays as follows: Defendants' opposition shall be filed no later than January 7, 2015, and Plaintiffs' reply shall be filed no later than January 19, 2015; and (3) Reset the MTD briefing schedule as follows: (a) If the Court grants the MTA: (i) Defendants' motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' third amended complaint shall be filed no later than 21 days after the order granting leave to amend; (ii) Plaintiffs' opposition shall be filed no later than 10 days after the motion filing; and (iii) Defendants' reply shall be filed no later than 10 days after the opposition filing; or (b) If the Court denies the MTA: (i) Plaintiffs' opposition to the MTD shall be filed no later than 10 days after the order denying leave to amend; and (ii) Defendants' reply shall be filed no later than 10 days after the opposition filing. (c) Computation of time under this paragraph shall be made pursuant to Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and Rule 6.4 of the Local Civil Rules of the Southern District of New York. SO ORDERED. ( Responses due by 1/7/2015, Replies due by 1/19/2015.) (Signed by Judge Analisa Torres on 12/11/2014) (ajs) (Entered: 12/11/2014)

Original Docket Text: ORDER granting 28 Motion to Amend/Correct ; denying 22 Motion to Dismiss. Having shown good cause, Plaintiffs' motion for leave to file a third amended class action complaint is GRANTED. Defendants' request for an order directing Plaintiffs to reimburse Defendants for the costs and fees with respect to the motion to dismiss the second amended complaint is DENIED. In accordance with the parties' joint stipulation dated December 11, 2014, it is ORDERED that: 1. Defendants shall file their motion to dismiss the third amended complaint by March 11, 2015; 2. Plaintiffs shall file their opposition by March 23, 2015; 3. Defendants shall reply by April 2, 2015. Decision on Defendants' motion for a temporary stay of discovery is held in abeyance, pending the Court's review of Defendants' motion to dismiss the third amended complaint. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge Analisa Torres on 2/18/2015) (ajs) (Entered: 02/19/2015)

Original Docket Text: ORDER denying 76 Motion for Summary Judgment; denying 90 Motion for Summary Judgment; terminating 110 Motion to Preclude. The Court denies the pending summary judgment motions. The case will now proceed to a bench trial, limited to issues of liability. The Court's intention, in order to achieve a prompt result, is to hold that trial in April 2017, when the Court has substantial availability. The Court directs counsel to confer by phone today as to the anticipated number of days that a bench trial would take, mindful that direct testimony at trial, per the Court's individual rules, see Individual Rule 5(C)(i), will be received by affidavit, and to notify the Court by letter due Monday, February 13, 2017, at noon, as to counsels' estimate as to the trial's lenghth. The Court's law clerk will reach out to counsel later Monday to set aside particular days in April for the bench trial. Upon identifying the trial dates, the Court will set a schedule for required pretrial submissions. The Clerk of Court is respectfully requested to terminate the motions pending at Dkts. 76, 90, and 110. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge Paul A. Engelmayer on 2/10/2017) (anc) (Entered: 02/10/2017)

Original Docket Text: ORDER terminating 124 Motion for Leave to Present Ajay Gupta's Direct Testimony Live at Trial. The Court has reviewed the letter from SDG Corporation, Dkt. 124, seeking leave at the upcoming bench trial to present the direct testimony of its witness Ajay Gupta in live form rather than by affidavit, and the letter in opposition by Laurus Capital Management, LCC, Dkt. 125. The Court directs that Mr. Gupta's direct testimony, like that of all other party witnesses, be presented by means of an affidavit. In light of SDG's stated concerns, the Court encourages SDG to assure that Mr. Gupta's affidavit be as comprehensive as possible. To the extent that SDG anticipates arguments by opposing counsel as to why Mr. Gupta's testimony as to particular facts may not be credible, SDG is encouraged to anticipate such arguments in preparing Mr. Gupta's affidavit. Given the potential significance of Mr. Gupta's testimony, the Court fully expects that Laurus will cross-examine him at trial, following which SDG will be at liberty to conduct a live re-direct examination of Mr. Gupta. For avoidance of doubt, to the extent that Laurus intends to submit deposition testimony of Mr. Gupta, such prior testimony is to be offered in the course of the cross-examination of Mr. Gupta, so that SDG has the opportunity, during re-direct examination, to examine Mr. Gupta about such prior statements (e.g., to develop relevant context for them). The Court is confident that, with the benefit of detailed direct testimony in affidavit form from Mr. Gupta and live cross and re-direct examination, it will be well-positioned to assess his credibility. (Signed by Judge Paul A. Engelmayer on 2/24/2017) (mro) (Entered: 02/27/2017)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: At yesterday's conference, the Court read aloud its findings of fact, conclusions of law, and a verdict in this case, in which a bench trial was held between April 24 and 27, 2017. Consequently, the Court orders the following relief: First, the Court grants declaratory relief to SDG on its claims pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C.  2201 and 2202. Specifically, the Court holds that (1) Erato's lien against SDG's assets, recorded by the Connecticut Secretary of State at file no. 2627336, has been validly and finally terminated and cannot be revived or executed upon, (2) the Master Security Agreement and the Guarantee and the Security Agreement signed by Mascon's Sandy Chandra in March 2008 are invalid, void, of no force or effect, and unenforceable, and (3) neither Erato and/or Laurus, nor any of their successors, assigns and affiliates, has a valid security interest, lien, or claim against SDG Corporation or any of its property or assets. Second, as to defendants' counterclaims, the Court finds SDG not liable for breach of the MSA and Guarantee. These documents were not valid or binding on SDG. Third, as to SDG's claim for tortious interference with business relations, the Court holds that defendants not liable. The Court finds that SDG failed to show the requisite bad faith or fraudulent conduct on defendants' part in imposing the lien on SDG. Because the Court has been advised by the parties that post-trial motions may be made, the Court directs the Clerk of Court not to enter judgment at this time, and to wait for further instruction from the Court before doing so. (Signed by Judge Paul A. Engelmayer on 5/18/2017) (rj) (Entered: 05/18/2017)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION AND ORDER; the Sponsor is and shall be free to offer to sell, and sell, the Units, or any of them, to any purchaser or purchaser. Any down payment or down payments hereafter paid into escrow in connection with a contract or contracts for such a sale or sales, whether paid to theEscrow Agent or to any other escrow agent, shall be free and clear of any claim or lien of the Receiver, the Commission, Yagalla or any other creditor of Yagalla, and may be disbursed by the Escrow Agent or any other escrow agent in accordance with the applicable purchase agreement. The Escrow Agent shall promptly pay the Escrow Funds, in their entirety, to the Receiver, who shall place all of the Escrow Funds in a separate interest-bearing escrow account that is not subject to fees, expenses, use or diminution. This Stipulation and Order is and shall be completely without prejudice to any claims or defenses of the Sponsor, the Receiver, the Commission, Yagalla or any other creditor of Yagalla with respect to (a) who is entitled to receive the Escrow Funds or any portion of those funds, and (b) whether or not the Sponsor is entitled to the entry of a judgment for the Dishonored Check and to enforce and collect upon that judgment. This Stipulation and Order does not affect any prior order to this Court that retains the prosecution of claims in this Court or any other courts. To the extent that any provisions of this Stipulation & Order are inconsistent with any prior orders of this Court, the prior orders shall be deemed modified hereby. ( signed by Judge Richard C. Casey ) (sac) (Entered: 04/09/2001)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION REGARDING BOSTON REAL ESTATE LEASE; on or approximately about 6/1/00, Asbury Capital Management, LLC. entered into an Indenture of Lease with Bravo Fifty Realty Trust, as Trustee of the 50 Federal Street Trust to rent office space in Boston, MA upon the terms and conditions contained herein. A copy of the Lease is annexed hereto, made a part hereof,, and marked as "Exhibit A." The Landlord represents that (i) Ashbury Management has defaulted on the Lease, (ii) Ashbury Management currently owes rent and legal expenses totaling approximately $25,000 and (iii) it is in possession of a security deposit in the amount of $9,660.00 which has been restrained by the Order. In consideration of the foregoing and other good and valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which is hereby acknowledged, the Receiver, the SEC and the Landlord, by and through their counsel, hereby agree as follows: The Receiver shall, upon written notice from the Receiver to the Landlord given on or before the expiration of 15 days after the Effective Date (i) surrender possession of the Office and allow the Landlord to re-enter the Office effective immediately for the purpose of re-letting the Office to a new tenant and (ii) terminate its obligations under the Lease effective as of the date of said written notice. Should the Receiver fail to exercise this option within the time provided, the Landlord shall be entitled to re-enter the Office and take possession thereof, and the Lease will be considered terminated as of the 15 day after the Effective Date. Any surrender to the Office, and termination of the Lease, purs. to terms set forth in this Stipulation shall be without prejudice to or waiver of any claims the Landlord may have against the defts under the Lease for matters occurring prior to the date of said termination and surrender, including but not limited to claims for unpaid unpaid rent and other charges, and claims relating to any mechanics' or materialmans' liens placed upon the Office or the building in which it is located by any contractor retained by the defts. ( signed by Judge Richard C. Casey ) (sac) (Entered: 04/09/2001)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: The objections are hereby overruled. The Court finds that the overall distribution plan, including the limitation on distribution to only investor-victims, is fair. The Internal Revenue Service (the "IRS") has agreed to forgo its priority claim to Mark Yagalla's assets on the condition that all funds marshaled by the Receiver are paid in restitution to investor-victims of the fraud committed by Mr. Yagalla and for the costs of administration. As the IRS's claim would eliminate most, if not all, of the Receivership assets, the limitation on distribution to investor-victims is necessary to ensure any distribution. SO ORDERED. Original Docket Text: ORDER REGARDING: (1) CONSOLIDATION OF SECURITIES ACTIONS, APPOINTMENT OF LEAD PLAINTIFF AND APPROVAL LEAD PLAINTIFF AND APPROVAL OF LEAD COUNSEL; (2) CONSOLIDATION OF DERIVATIVE ACTIONS AND APPOINTMENT OF PLAINTIFFS' EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND LIAISON COUNSEL; (3)CONSOLIDATION OF ERISA ACTIONS AND APPOINTMENT OF INTERIM CO-LEAD COUNSEL; AND (4)SCHEDULING OF THE FILING OF CONSOLIDATED AMENDED COMPLAINTS IN EACH OF THE ACTIONS AND RESPONSES THERETO: It is hereby ordered that Pursuant to F.R.C.P. 42(a) and Section 21D(a)(3)(B) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, 15 U.S.C. 78u-4(a)(3)(B)(ii), the Securities Actions are consolidated into the docket number 07cv9633 for all purposes including, but not limited to, discovery, pretrial proceedings and trial. Pursuant to Section 21D(a)(3)(B) of the Exchange Act, 15 U.S.C. 78u-4(a)(3), Ohio STRS is appointed Lead Plaintiff in the Securities Action for the proposed class of persons and entities who purchased or otherwise acquired Merrill Lynch securities. Ohio STRS' choice of co-lead counsel is approved. Accordingly, the law firms of Kaplan Fox & Kilsheimer LLP, Berger & Montague, P.C. and Barrack Rodos & Bacine are appointed co-Lead Counsel for the Securities Action. Pursuant to F.R.C.P. 42(a), the Derivative Actions are consolidated into the docket number 07cv9696 for all purposes including but not limited to discovery, pretrial proceedings and trial. The Court appoints Brower Piven, A Professional Corporation, Johnson Bottini LLP and Saxena White LLP as Plaintiffs' Executive Committee in the Derivative Action, and appoints Brower Piven as Plaintiffs' Liaison Counsel in the Derivative Action. Pursuant to F.R.C.P. 42(a), the ERISA Actions are consolidated into the docket number 07cv10268 for all purposes including but not limited to discovery, pretrial proceeding and trial. Pursuant to F.R.C.P. 23(g)(2)(A) for the ERISA Action, the Court appoints the law firms of Keller Rohrback L.L.P. and Cohen, Milstein, Hausfeld & Toll, P.L.L.C. as interim co-lead counsel to act on behalf of the putative class. The docket in 07cv9633 shall constitute the Master Docket for the Securities Action, Derivative Action and ERISA Action. A copy of this Order shall be placed in all dockets identified herein. The Clerk of the Court is directed to close each of those dockets, other than the dockets in the Securities Action 07cv9633, Derivative Action 07cv9696 and ERISA Action, 07cv10268. Lead Plaintiff in the Securities Action, Plaintiff's Executive Committee in the Derivative Action and Interim Co-Lead Counsel in the ERISA Action shall each file a separate Consolidated Amended Complaint no later than April 21, 2008. Defendants in each of the Securities Action, 07cv9633, Derivative Action, 07cv9696 and ERISA 07cv10268, shall have to and including June 20, 2008 to answer, move or otherwise respond to each Consolidated Amended Complaints. In the event that defendants file motions to dismiss the Consolidated Complaint in one or more Securities Action, 07cv9633, Derivative Actions 07cv9696 and/or ERISA 07cv10268, applicable, shall serve any opposition to such motions no later July 21, 2008. Defendants shall serve any reply papers in further support of any such motions to dismiss no later than August 19, 2008. (Signed by Judge Leonard B. Sand on 3/12/2008) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:07-cv-09633-LBS et al.(jpo) (Entered: 03/13/2008)

Original Docket Text: ORDER: At an in-court conference earlier today, October 23, 2008, in the Derivative Action, 07 Civ. 9696, the Court indicated its intention to resolve all motions to dismiss in all three Actions (i.e., the Securities Action, the Derivative Action, and the ERISA Action) by no later than February 17, 2009, and then to have all parties embark on consolidated discovery in all three Actions, with such discovery to be completed no later than October 20, 2009, with a likely trial date of sometime in February, 2010. (Certain limited discovery in some of the Actions, related to injunctive relief or other special purposes, may possibly occur prior to February 17, 2009, a matter on which the Court will shortly be receiving papers from the parties.) If any counsel in either the Securities Action, 07 Civ. 9633, or the ERISA Action, 07 Civ. 10268, objects to any of the above-underscored dates, such counsel should convene a conference call with the Court and other affected parties by no later than Thursday, October 30, 2008 and the Court will consider such objections and issue a further order if necessary. Independently, counsel in the ERISA case should arrange to call the Court by no later than Monday, October 27, 2008 to discuss motions to dismiss related to that Action. The previous referral of these Actions to Magistrate Judge Eaton for all pre-trial purposes is hereby modified and clarified as follows: All discovery matters will remain referred to Magistrate Judge Eaton, including any motions or applications related solely to discovery. The Magistrate Judge, however, will not have the authority to extend the October 20, 2009 date, now set for completion of all discovery. All other motions or applications of any kind whatever must first be brought to the undersigned's attention through a joint conference call with the Court and affected parties, at which time the Court will determine whether the motion or application is best resolved by this Court or should be referred to the Magistrate Judge. (Signed by Judge Jed S. Rakoff on 10/23/08) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:07-cv-09633-JSR-DFE et al.(tro) (Entered: 10/27/2008)

Original Docket Text: STIPULATION AND ORDER: NOW, THEREFORE, IT IS STIPULATED AND AGREED, by and among the parties hereto, through their respective attorneys, that: 1. The Class Claims (Counts XIII through XVII) of the Third Amended Complaint are hereby dismissed with prejudice, and the Third Amended Complaint is deemed amended accordingly pursuant to Rule 15(a)(2) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. This Order does not apply to Counts I through XII of the Third Amended Complaint and is without prejudice to any of defendants' positions with respect to those counts or the propriety of any amendments to the Second Amended Complaint. 2. No further notice of the dismissal of the Class Claims shall be given to the Class in view of the notice previously given to the Class in conjunction with the Delaware Court of Chancery's hearing with respect to the Settlement, which the Delaware Court of Chancery found to be due and adequate notice of the Class Claims, the proceedings, the Settlement and the terms and conditions of the dismissal of the Class Claims. Original Docket Text: ORDER: As stated during a telephone conference held today, the Court hereby grants plaintiff's request to conduct narrow discovery via a few interrogatories on the issue of whether Bank of America owned Merrill Lynch stock at the time of the alleged wrongdoing underlying this action. Original Docket Text: MEMORANDUM ORDER Therefore, pursuant to Rule 41 of the Delaware Supreme Court, the Court hereby certifies to the Delaware Supreme Court the question of whether a plaintiff seeking to bring a double derivative suit under Delaware law in the kind of circumstances here presented (i.e., where the plaintiff was a pre-merger shareholder in the acquired company at the time of the alleged wrongdoing at that company and,because of a stock-for-stock merger, thereafter becomes and remains a shareholder in the acquiring company) must also demonstrate to establish standing that, at the time of the alleged wrongdoing at the acquired company, (a) the plaintiff owned stock in the acquiring company, and (b) the acquiring company owned stock in the acquired company. In order to allow the Delaware Supreme Court time to address -- or to indicate that it will address -- this question, if it so chooses, but so as not to delay indefinitely these on going actions in federal court, the Court hereby stays all proceedings in these actions, unless otherwise explicitly ordered by the Court,until July 19, 2010. So Ordered (Signed by Judge Jed S. Rakoff on 3/9/2010) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:07-cv-09633-JSR-JLC, 1:07-cv-09696-JSR-DFE(js) Modified on 3/9/2010 (js). Modified on 3/9/2010 (js). (Entered: 03/09/2010)

Topic Output: [('motion for summary judgment', 0.4828296), ('Complaint and motion', 0.2667346), ('motion to dismiss', 0.2327298), ('Amended Complaint and motion', 0.017705955)]

Original Docket Text: CERTIFICATION OF QUESTION OF LAW: NOW, THEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED that the following question of law is certified to the Supreme Court of the State of Delaware for disposition in accordance with Rule 41 of the Supreme Court:Whether plaintiffs in a double derivative action under Delaware law, who were pre-merger shareholders in the acquired company and who are current shareholders, by virtue of a stock-for-stock merger, in the post-merger parent company, must also demonstrate that, at the time of the alleged wrong doing at the acquired company, (a) they owned stock in the acquiring company. (b) the acquiring company owned stock in the acquired company. (Signed by Judge Jed S. Original Docket Text: ORDER: By letter dated June 1, 2010, the Clerk of the Supreme Court of Delaware asked the parties about the status of the stay in the above-captioned cases, and the parties informed her that the current stay is in effect only until July 19, 2010. However, the Court's Memorandum Order of March 9, 2010 set that date in the expectation that it would provide sufficient time for the Delaware Supreme Court to "indicate [whether] it will address" the certified question, 3/09/10 Mem. Order, which it has now done. Although no party has asked for a further extension, it would be this Court's view that, now that the Delaware Supreme Court has accepted certification, this Court would likely rule favorably on any application of any party to extend the stay until after the Delaware Supreme Court issues its decision. Counsel for the parties are hereby directed to furnish a copy of this Order to the Clerk of the Supreme Court of Delaware. (Signed by Judge Jed S. Rakoff on 6/4/2010) Filed In Associated Cases: 1:07-cv-09633-JSR, 1:07-cv-09696-JSR-DFE(jfe) Modified on 6/7/2010 (jfe). (Entered: 06/07/2010)
